page.title: 04Seventy Years in Drayton (3)
page.content: Then he spread it on the road and a steam roller would roll it backwards and forwards to flatten it. There were only horses and carts and a few bicycles then. There were eleven farms here then and a large one at Midelney. Now there are only four in the village. We had a blacksmith, a carpenter and wheelwright, a butcher and, at one time, three shops. Now we have none. But we have a post office and a pub. We have a lovely old church and a small chapel. The men still sing Wassail around the vllage on Old Christmas Eve, January 5th. We still have a Woman's Club and they have their Annual Walk in June. They have a banner with clasped hands on it and the words "Bear Ye One Anothers Burdens"and the women have ribbons on their coats.
